IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: Foster Care, Developmental Services, Residential Treatment, Home-based services and consultation are the broad scope divisions which make up NAFI Connecticut Inc.
IRS990.MissionDescription: Creating diverse & innovative services. NAFI CT is a multi-service agency that provides programming, consultation and individual support services to youth, families & young adults in a variety of settings.
IRS990.Description: NAFICT operates two trauma informed, gender responsive residential facilities serving young ladies between the ages of 11-18. The goal of the treatment is to prepare the young ladies for their next steps in life. The school on each campus compliments therapeutic mileu for a holistic approach to treatment. Vocational programs include graphic design, building trades, horticulture and culinary arts. *See Schedule O*

Activity2.Description: NAFICT Group Homes serve developmentally delayed males between the ages of 10 - 21. Through an increase in adaptive skills, daily living skills, and overall functioning, residents will maximize their levels of independence and community integration.

Activity3.Description: Multi-Systemic Therapy Program is an evidenced-based model providing intensive, family-based treatment for youth 11-17 with identified substance abuse issues and/or behavioral challenges. The goal of the community-based programs is to strengthen and stabilize family ecology.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Identifier: Revenue included on return not in financial statements
Expenses included in financial statements not on return

GeneralExplanation.Explanation: *YES! - Youth Equipped For Success* This program provides services to youth in the Juvenile Justice System identified as medium risk. YES! Employs multiple evidence based interventions that target dynamic risk factors and works to strengthen and reinforce protective factors. YES! offers both center based and in home services. The in home services model, Functional Family Therapy (FFT), is a nationally recognized Blueprints program, and has proven successful for the treatment of delinquency, substance abuse and violence for at risk youth. YES! Center-based component offers a variety of group curricula to target the various needs of youth. The cognitive behavioral interventions provide trauma informed, gender responsive group therapy to reduce recidivism and promote protective factors. *MST TAY (transitional age youth)* The Multi-Systemic Therapy Transitional Age Youth Program is an evidenced based model that provides intensive individual treatment for transitional age youth (ages 17-20) with both a recent history of criminal involvement and mental health challenges. The goal of MST-TAY treatment is to stabilize youth with significant mental health impairment and other high risk behaviors within the community through intensive multi-weekly treatment sessions for up to six months.

Licensed bed capacity at Touchstone Program changed from 26 to 16. NAFI CT discontinued Building Stronger Families Program and was awarded The Multi-Systemic Therapy Transitional Age Youth Program (MST TAY) in its place.

Line 4a NAFICT operates two trauma informed, gender responsive residential facilities serving young ladies between the ages of 11-18. The goal of the treatment is to prepare the young ladies for their next steps in life. The school on each campus compliments therapeutic mileu for a holistic approach to treatment. Vocational programs include graphic design, building trades, horticulture and culinary arts. Program Achievements between the two facilities include: a. Implementing building trades and graphic technology vocational programming. b. An interdisciplinary team inclusive of staff and residents designed a new gender responsive behavior motivation system. c. Development of Risk Management Committee to examine restraint and workers compensation claims. Line 4e Other Program Services NAFICT's other multiservice programs include: short and long-term foster care; case management and clinical home-based services. In addition, we offer programs for developmentally delayed clients living in apartments and group homes.
Colleen Pollard and Donner Pollard have a family relationship.

North American Family Institute (NAFI) is the sole corporate member of NAFI Connecticut, Inc. [NAFICT]. NAFICT pays a management fee of $1,016,257 to NAFI for oversight of financial, budgeting, human resource operations, and exempt operations. NAFI also provides accounting and auditing services, personnel policies and benefits, and information technology backbone for the subsidiary corporate offices.
North American Family Institute, Inc. is sole member of NAFI Connecticut, Inc. and may elect members of the governing board.

Information is gathered from the business office/executive directors by the Chief Financial Officer and used to populate the Form 990's in conjunction with independent tax auditors. Once completed, the draft form is reviewed and forwarded by the CFO to the designated committee for review prior to its submission. This designated committee has been authorized to review and approve the Form 990 on behalf of the Board of Directors.

In addition to submission of signed Board Member Annual Statement affirming receipt of the Conflict of Interest Policy, that they have read and understand the policy, that they agree to comply with the policy and understand that the corporation is charitable and must engage in activities which accomplish its charitable purposes, Board members have a duty to disclose possible conflicts of interest. When such a disclosure is made, the Board of Directors will discuss the issue with the interested party. The interested party will then leave the Board meeting while a determination of a conflict of interest is discussed and voted upon. If the Board has reasonable cause to believe that a Director has failed to disclose a possible conflict of interest, the Board will afford that Director an opportunity to explain. The Board will conduct further investigation as warranted by the circumstances. That Director will be recuse from the Board meeting while a determination of a conflict of interest is discussed and voted upon. If the Board determines that the Board member failed to disclose an actual or possible conflict of interest, it shall take appropriate disciplinary and corrective action.

Annually, the executive director, board of directors and parent organization ceo participate in an evaluation process. The executive director completes a self evaluation reflecting on accomplishments, areas of growth and goals for the coming year. The board of directors also completes an evaluation summary for the executive director as does the CEO of the parent organization. This information is reviewed and discussed at an executive session of the board of directors. Salary considerations are part of this process and include approvals by the CEO of the parent organization and the board of directors. The decision is recorded on an employee change form with an explanation for the action taken. The form with the written evaluations attached is signed by the executive director, parent organization CEO, and the director of human resources. Other key employees of the organization are reviewed by the executive director using a similar process and salary considerations are a part of the overall budget approved by the board of directors. The NAFI legal counsel conducts a targeted review of salaries of similar organizations and form 990s of other organizations to establish a comparable level of compensation.
The organization's governing documents, conflict of interest policy, financial statements, and Form 990 are available upon request. The Form 990 is also posted on www.guidestar.org.

NAFI and affiliated corporations may periodically make short term loans, not to exceed one year, to its affiliated corporation, secured by documentation evidencing such indebtedness. The documentation shall include date and amount of the request, interest rate and other appropriate terms approved by the Executive Director of Administrative Services and the Executive Director of the borrowing affiliated corporation. In fiscal 2010, NAFICT provided support to its affiliates through use of certain cash reserves with an interest fee, based on prime rate less 0.50. The amount of related interest income recorded in the accompanying statement of activities for the year ended June 30, 2010 was $46,063.
